DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court to Begin High-Speed Opinion Transmission
Eds: Subs next-to-last graf to restore dropped words `might be increased'
DOC.TEXT: Texts of Supreme Court opinions soon will be available via computer within minutes of their announcement from the bench, a court official said Monday. James R. Donovan, director of data systems for the high court, said the experimental system will be put in operation, perhaps by spring, for a two-year run. During an 18-month study into speedy delivery of high court opinions in electronic form, a special committee headed by Donovan originally envisioned letting some private agency distribute the opinions to all interested parties. But it was later decided the court itself should do the job. The system ``is designed to simultaneously transmit the court's opinions to a specific group of recipients, limited to those who are in the business of disseminating information,'' Donovan said in a letter of announcement. The number of recipients initially will be kept down by ``practical limits of system capacity and workload imposed upon court staff,'' Donovan said. He said the number of recipients, each of which will pay an annual subscription rate expected to be set at $500, might be increased if there is demand and if the experiment indicates expansion is feasible. Recipients, to be chosen by Donovan's committee, will be expected to provide necessary common equipment, such as telephone lines.
